Guilty Until Proven Innocent "Perhaps the bleakest fact of all is that the death penalty is imposed not only in a freakish and discriminatory manner, but also in some cases upon defendants who are actually innocent."
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6838750_0172.3
- Supreme Court Justice William J. Brennan Jr. 1994
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6838750_0172.4
Innocent people are on death row and have been executed
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6838750_0172.5
* More than 110 people have been exonerated from death row since 1972, including 22 from the state of Florida alone.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6838750_0172.6
(Death Penalty Information Center) Â· * The system of capital punishment is flawed at both the state and federal level.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6838750_0172.7
On the federal level, 3.5% of persons whom the Attorney General has attempted to execute have been innocent.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6838750_0172.8
In one example of state-level problems, Illinois (prior to Governor Ryan's blanket commutation) had an error rate of at least 4.5%.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6838750_0172.9
(American Civil Liberties Union) Â· * A study identified 23 instances in the last century in which a person with an extraordinarily strong case of innocence had been executed by the government.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6838750_0172.10
(H. Bedeau & M. Radelet, "Miscarriages of Justice in Potentially Capital Cases" Stanford Law Review, 1987)
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6838750_0172.11
Recent cases of possible mistaken execution
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6838750_0172.12
* Virginia executed Joseph O'Dell on July 23, 1997 despite the existence of DNA evidence that could have proved O'Dell's innocence.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6838750_0172.13
The courts refused to consider this new evidence because Virginia law says that any evidence found after 21 days is inadmissible in proving the innocence of a convicted person.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6838750_0172.14
* Texas executed Jesse Jacobs on January 4, 1995 despite the prosecution's admission that arguments they made at Jacobs' trial were false.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6838750_0172.15
Jacobs was convicted after the state introduced evidence that he, rather than his co-defendant, pulled the trigger on the day of the murder.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6838750_0172.16
At the subsequent trial of the co-defendant, the state reversed its story and said it was the co-defendant, not Jacobs, who pulled the trigger.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6838750_0172.17
The prosecution vouched for the credibility of Jacobs' testimony that he did not commit the shooting and did not even know that his co-defendant had a gun.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6838750_0172.18
Jacobs' co-defendant was also convicted, though he was not sentenced to death.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6838750_0172.19
* Texasexecuted Robert Nelson Drew on August 2, 1994 after refusing to give him a new hearing after another man signed an affidavit in which he confessed to the murder, thereby exonerating Drew.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6838750_0172.20
* Texasexecuted Leonel Herrera in 1993 despite compelling evidence of his innocence.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6838750_0172.21
A former Texas judge submitted an affidavit stating that another man had confessed to the crime for which Herrera was facing execution.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6838750_0172.22
Numerous other pieces of new evidence also threw doubt on his conviction.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6838750_0172.23
According to the Supreme Court, however, that proof was not sufficient to stop his execution because of the late stage of his appeal.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6838750_0172.24
* Virginiaexecuted Roger Keith Coleman in 1992.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6838750_0172.25
Coleman's appellate attorneys misread the statute governing the time frame for submitting an appeal and filed their brief one day too late.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6838750_0172.26
The Virginia state courts held that the one-day-late filing was the equivalent of no filing at all and refused to review his issues.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6838750_0172.27
The federal courts subsequently held that Coleman could not raise a federal claim because he had waived his state review.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6838750_0172.28
Finally, the Supreme Court determined that Coleman could not complain that it was his attorneys who erred because he was not entitled to an attorney in the first place.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6838750_0172.29
No court ever fully reviewed the evidence of his innocence prior to his execution.

Bush budget lacks funds for Baghdad embassy
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6850335_0004.3
By Peter Cohn CongressDaily May 17, 2004 As Congress prepares to delve into the administration's $25 billion fiscal 2005 request for military operations in Iraq and Afghanistan, a debate also is simmering about whether and how to add funds for the June 30 transition of sovereignty to an interim Iraqi government.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6850335_0004.4
The State Department will be charged with staffing, security and other startup costs for interim embassy facilities -- up to $1 billion in 2005, according to department estimates.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6850335_0004.5
But the Bush administration has not requested those funds in either its regular 2005 budget or in the new military funding request.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6850335_0004.6
That sum does not include the cost of constructing a new state-of-the-art embassy in Baghdad, which at up to $1.5 billion would dwarf the current largest State Department project -- a new embassy compound in Beijing expected to cost up to $450 million.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6850335_0004.7
The situation has some influential lawmakers concerned about having to shift funds around in an already tighter-than-usual budget year.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6850335_0004.8
"You can't send people over there without protection," said House Commerce-Justice-State Appropriations Subcommittee Chairman Frank Wolf, R-Va., in a recent interview.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6850335_0004.9
"You've got to deal with that issue.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6850335_0004.10
We'll do the best we can to meet the needs."
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6850335_0004.11
In a hearing last week before the House International Relations Committee, Undersecretary of State Marc Grossman said 2005 costs to operate the U.S. mission in Baghdad would amount to about $1 billion, which the administration would seek as part of its supplemental request, expected early next year.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6850335_0004.12
After the new fiscal year begins Oct. 1, Grossman said the agency would make do with funds appropriated in the Commerce-Justice-State spending bill until the new supplemental request is approved.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6850335_0004.13
Grossman said costs for July through October are estimated at $483 million, with $477 million in fiscal 2004 funds available with another $6 million through reprogramming.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6850335_0004.14
However, Deputy Secretary of State Richard Armitage told the House Foreign Operations Appropriations Subcommittee in late April the agency would be $40 million to $60 million short of the necessary 2004 funds, but that he did not anticipate legislative relief at this time.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6850335_0004.15
He also said continued peacekeeping needs in Liberia, Sudan and Haiti could place additional demands on the 2005 supplemental expected early next year.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6850335_0004.16
With the appearance last week of President Bush's 2005 budget "amendment" for the Pentagon's needs in Iraq and Afghanistan, lawmakers are beginning to examine whether the additional funds should be limited for military purposes.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6850335_0004.17
Senate Appropriations Committee Chairman Ted Stevens, R-Alaska, said the size of the package his panel drafts could increase to as much as $50 billion and the situation on the ground after June 30 would play a role.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6850335_0004.18
He indicated the administration should have almost unfettered flexibility to shift funds around to meet potential needs that arise, and that his panel was unlikely to approve the funds -- likely as part of the 2005 Defense spending bill -- until a post-June 30 review of the situation.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6850335_0004.19
House Foreign Operations Appropriations Subcommittee Chairman Jim Kolbe, R-Ariz., also a senior member of the Commerce-Justice-State Appropriations Subcommittee, was more specific.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6850335_0004.20
"I'm concerned this supplemental does not have anything in it for operating the embassy" in Baghdad, he said.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6850335_0004.21
Kolbe said he has discussed the issue with Armitage and other White House officials.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6850335_0004.22
Some lawmakers are demanding assurances that adequate funds will be available or may consider adding funds.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6850335_0004.23
But he added that "it would set a very bad precedent" to fund embassy activities in the Defense appropriations bill.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6850335_0004.24
"We're looking at different ways to fund it," Kolbe said.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6850335_0004.25
A congressional delegation led by House Speaker Dennis Hastert, R-Ill., that included Kolbe, Wolf, House Defense Appropriations Subcommittee Chairman Jerry Lewis, R-Calif., and House Armed Services Committee Chairman Duncan Hunter, R-Calif., met with Bush administration officials at the White House last Thursday to discuss the situation in Iraq.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192783-6850335_0004.26
House Appropriations Committee Chairman Bill Young, R-Fla., said embassy needs would be met in the context of the Commerce-Justice-State spending bill, but also did not rule out adding funds in addition to the $25 billion military request, arguing there is room for "substantially more" in the 2005 budget resolution, which contains an allowance for $50 billion for Iraq and Afghanistan.

bolt-eng-DF-199-192784-5873990_0015.6

bolt-eng-DF-199-192784-5873990_0015.18
Executive Summary
bolt-eng-DF-199-192784-5873990_0015.19
Over the past century, our nation expanded the franchise and knocked down myriad barriers to full electoral participation.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192784-5873990_0015.20
In 2011, however, that momentum abruptly shifted.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192784-5873990_0015.21
State governments across the country enacted an array of new laws making it harder to register or to vote.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192784-5873990_0015.22
Some states require voters to show government-issued photo identification, often of a type that as many as one in ten voters do not have.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192784-5873990_0015.23
Other states have cut back on early voting, a hugely popular innovation used by millions of Americans.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192784-5873990_0015.24
Two states reversed earlier reforms and once again disenfranchised millions who have past criminal convictions but who are now taxpaying members of the community.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192784-5873990_0015.25
Still others made it much more difficult for citizens to register to vote, a prerequisite for voting.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192784-5873990_0015.26
These new restrictions fall most heavily on young, minority, and low-income voters, as well as on voters with disabilities.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192784-5873990_0015.27
This wave of changes may sharply tilt the political terrain for the 2012 election.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192784-5873990_0015.28
Based on the Brennan Centerâs analysis of the 19 laws and two executive actions that passed in 14 states, it is clear that:
bolt-eng-DF-199-192784-5873990_0015.29
These new laws could make it significantly harder for more than five million eligible voters to cast ballots in 2012.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192784-5873990_0015.31
Of the 12 likely battleground states, as assessed by an August Los Angeles Times analysis of Gallup polling, five have already cut back on voting rights (and may pass additional restrictive legislation), and two more are currently considering new restrictions.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192784-5873990_0015.32
States have changed their laws so rapidly that no single analysis has assessed the overall impact of such moves.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192784-5873990_0015.33
Although it is too early to quantify how the changes will impact voter turnout, they will be a hindrance to many voters at a time when the United States continues to turn out less than two thirds of its eligible citizens in presidential elections and less than half in midterm elections.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192784-5873990_0015.34
This study is the first comprehensive roundup of all state legislative action thus far in 2011 on voting rights, focusing on new laws as well as state legislation that has not yet passed or that failed.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192784-5873990_0015.35
This snapshot may soon be incomplete: the second halves of some state legislative sessions have begun.

bolt-eng-DF-199-192784-5873990_0017.3
WASHINGTON â The Supreme Court has thrown out a ruling on the use of a certain electronic voting machine in Texas.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192784-5873990_0017.4
The high court without comment declared moot an appeal of a ruling against Dallas County, Texas.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192784-5873990_0017.5
That county was sued by the Texas Democratic Party over the use of iVotronic machines.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192784-5873990_0017.6

bolt-eng-DF-199-192784-5873990_0017.7
Officials say the Justice Department approved the machines, but federal courts in Texas say the straight-line voting change was not explicitly approved.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192784-5873990_0017.8
Chad Dunn, the lawyer for the Texas Democratic Party, said now the county must get preclearance from the Justice Department before using the machines.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192784-5873990_0017.9
The high court declared the case against the machines moot since the Justice Department has now cleared the machines, and ordered another part back to court to decide a fight over attorney fees.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192784-5873990_0017.10
Before machines, Dallas County used paper ballots.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192784-5873990_0017.11
If a voter selected a straight ticket, and that partyâs candidate, his or her vote for that candidate would count.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192784-5873990_0017.12
The cases are Dallas County v Texas Democratic Party, 10-755 and 10-1183.

bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607332_0002.26
Some folks caused lots of trips to the doctor as people caused themselves pain CREATING a gait problem where there wasn't one --- making adjustment of the "natural" alignment.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607332_0002.27
If you want to try the negative heel technology at half the price the current "Earth Energetics" seems to garner positive comments:
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607332_0002.29
their {mbt and Chung-shi shoes} over two-hundred-dollar price tag, plus the fact that some reviewer said Earth shoes had the same negative heel technology for a much lower price, convinced me to buy a pair of Earth Energetics.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607332_0002.30
I put them on the afternoon they were delivered.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607332_0002.31
I must admit that it took a bit of getting used to as it felt as though I was walking uphill.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607332_0002.32
Luckily, that passed quickly and I began using them while on the treadmill the next morning.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607332_0002.33
I now walk two miles every single day in them and that is with my treadmill fully inclined.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607332_0002.34
I love the Earth shoes so much that I bought several other styles for every day wear.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607332_0002.35
I have had a problem knee in the past and found that wearing the Earth shoes seemed to prevent the occasional flare-up of pain and swelling I used to get if I overdid it.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607332_0002.36
I recently ordered my second pair of Energetics as I had put hundreds of miles on that first pair, and I read somewhere that you should replace your athletic shoes after 500 miles."
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607332_0002.37
Take the advice of a guy who has experienced knee and back problems and was helped immensely by custom made orthotics and a good Orthopedic MD's checkups.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607332_0003.1

bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607332_0003.4

bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607332_0005.3
<a href="http://www.runnersworld.com/cda/shoelabshoefinder/0,7154,s6-240-325-329-0-0-0-0-0,00.html" title="http://www.runnersworld.com/cda/shoelabshoefinder/0,7154,s6-240-325-329-0-0-0-0-0,00.html" target="_EXT">http://www.runnersworld.com/cda/shoelabshoefinder/0,7154,s6-240-325-329-0-0-0-0-0,00.html</a>
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607332_0005.4
about pronation...
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607332_0005.5
<a href="http://www.runnersworld.com/cda/shoefinder_description/1,,s6-240-325-329-0-0-0-0-0,00.html" title="http://www.runnersworld.com/cda/shoefinder_description/1,,s6-240-325-329-0-0-0-0-0,00.html" target="_EXT">http://www.runnersworld.com/cda/shoefinder_description/1,,s6-240-325-329-0-0-0-0-0,00.html</a>
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607332_0006.1
It helps when picking out the right shoes to find out if your feet toe-in or tow-out (laterally) -- supinate or pronate.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607332_0006.2
That way you can choose the right shoe as some shoes benefit one type of gait tendency over the other.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607332_0006.3
The simplest way to determine this (your individual way of wearing and walking/running in shoes) is to examine an old pair of running shoes and check the wear pattern.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607332_0006.4
Excessive wear on the inside of the front part of the shoe indicates over pronation, such wear on the outside of the front of the shoe indicates supination.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607332_0007.1
similar comment...
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607332_0007.2
what I used to call supination is now called underpronation, at least on my link.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607332_0008.1
Same difference.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607332_0008.2
Supination = under pronation.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607332_0008.3
Try not to get too hung up on figuring out terminology as a well-versed athletic shoe store (not often a Foot Locker or typical mall store) will be able to advise you by looking at the wear pattern on your shoes or a well-worn pair of running shoes and advise you accordingly.

Hey Loren
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607570_0012.3
It is very difficult, especially with a young family.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607570_0012.4
I would recommend you get these enterology tests done -(these could come back negative and inidcating IBS - which isn't wholly helpful because it does mean a change in eating habits, dealing with stress etc...
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607570_0012.5
this could be caused by the fact you have a lot of pain to deal with i.e. your joints, back pain etc, and especially the fatigue.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607570_0012.6
If the enterologist does not come up with a definitive dx, then ask him to refer you to a rheumatologist (you call them immunologists in the USA).
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607570_0012.7
Ask specifically for the ESR and PV tests which will indicate "itis" - inflammation going on somewhere - ie arthritis, SLE, ulceritis - anything with an 'itis' going on with the parameters we've talked about here.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607570_0012.8
RA/SLE - specific test - Rheumatoid factor (you can have RA without the factor) and anti-DNA and antiRNA tests.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607570_0012.9
There are important.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607570_0012.10
The C4 test you were talking about may include the usual tests I have here - CRP (reactive protein), AST (Liver Function Test) and ALK (alk phospate) - these are strong indicators for inflammatory arthritis type symptons and connective tissue disease, incorporating SLE.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607570_0012.11
Also the base RBC, WBC neutrophils, eosinophils etc. (bog standard blood tests).
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607570_0012.12
The first mentioned are very specific tests and "pretty routine" - all they need to do is take a few extra vials (mine are 8 at a time).
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607570_0012.13
Other than that, I would really push for reassurance about the chest pains...
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607570_0012.14
that would be my priority if I were you...
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607570_0012.15
You haven't described the pain, could these be anxiety pains...
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607570_0012.16
worrying about what's wrong.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607570_0012.17
Whatever it is, you need to see someone soon about that.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607570_0012.18
with your diet and bloating - try cutting down on your carbs - bread, pasta, cereals with wheat, bread...
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607570_0012.19
that sort of thing...
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607570_0012.20
dairy produce...
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607570_0012.21
try maybe for a couple weeks and see if it makes a difference.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607570_0012.22
Carbs make a huge difference to IBS if that what it could be.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607570_0012.23

bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6607570_0012.24

Zoloft literally saved my life flushd....
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6610506_0018.2
it also gave me back such a huge portion of my life that I'm forever grateful the drug was developed.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6610506_0018.3
I've spoken before about my anxiety attacks here, so won't go into detail expect to say they were daily and were preventing me from having any sort of life.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6610506_0018.4
I was given the same dosage to start, 25mg to increase to 50mg hold there if it worked, or increase, etc.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6610506_0018.5

bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6610506_0018.6
anything to get me over my resistance and started on the med.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6610506_0018.7
Anxiety, physically, is your body raping itself of its seritonin.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6610506_0018.8
It uses up all your seritonin, looks for more, which you can't produce fast enough, so you become anxious/panic.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6610506_0018.9
It was important for me to know this as I could visualize the battle going on and how I could fix it.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6610506_0018.10
Zoloft is a SRRI - Seritonin Reuptake Inhibitor.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6610506_0018.11
It creates a block, a wall between the cells so one cell can only take so much seritonin at one time, and allows the other cells to produce a normal stockpile....
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6610506_0018.12
now this is not medical talk of course, but it helped me.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6610506_0018.13
I was warned my anxiety might actually Increase temporarily, as my body was trying to grab the seritonin, and couldn't get it, and freaked out.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6610506_0018.14
Don't worry, that's temporary.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6610506_0018.15
Then, you will start to normalize, and remember what it is like to relax, concentrate and enjoy things you had cut out of your life.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192794-6610506_0018.16

The Effects of a False Allegation of Child Sexual Abuse on an Intact Middle Class Family1 Â· Darrell W. Richardson* Â· ABSTRACT: The personal, clinical, and legal experience of an intact family of four in which which a false allegation of sexual abuse was made by the daughter toward the father was reported.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0054.2
The family was followed for two years.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0054.3
The experience destroyed the family and the parents and children all suffered depression, stress, rage, distress, hurt, and alienation.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0054.4
This case study parallels the available literature which indicates that a false allegation of sexual abuse is destructive and traumatic.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0054.5
On his way to work, a clinical psychologist had no way of knowing he was about to be arrested.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0054.6
As he got out of his car, two police officers approached him, asked him who he was, placed him under arrest, handcuffed him, and drove him off to jail.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0054.7
He had been charged with sexually abusing his two-year-old daughter (Spiegel 1986).
bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0054.8
I know of several similar incidents.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0054.9
A clinical psychologist was investigated by Child Protective Services for allegedly molesting his three-year-old daughter.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0054.10
A manager in a local supermarket was investigated for allegedly abusing his seventeen-year-old son, a local football star.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0054.11
He was fired as soon as the investigation became public.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0054.12
A drug and alcohol counselor was fired because it was rumored that he molested a counselee.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0054.13
A woman left her husband, a young army N.C.O., and informed him that she intended to keep all the appliances, furniture, and any other possessions she wanted (whether or not they belonged to her).
bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0054.14
And if he tried to stop her, she would turn him in for sexual abuse.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0054.15
The N.C.O. did nothing.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0054.16
His rationale was that his career in the service would be ruined.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0054.17
The common strand in all these situations was that the allegations were found to be false.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0054.18
The clinical psychologist spent $50,000 in his defense, lost his practice and most of his friends (Spiegel 1986).
bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0054.19
The second clinical psychologist spent nearly $35,000 in Juvenile Court in his defense (criminal charges were never filed).
bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0054.20
Both psychologists reported suicidal thoughts, anxiety, and depression.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0054.21
The supermarket manager lost his job, his home, filed bankruptcy, and went through a divorce.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0054.22
He related these tragedies to the intervention of the state.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0054.23
The drug and alcohol counselor lost his job because of the rumor, even though a check of the local law enforcement agencies (city, county, and state) found no charges filed, nor was there any complaint filed with CPS. The N.C.O. was blackmailed by his former spouse.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0054.24
Why were there divorces?
bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0054.25

bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0054.26

bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0054.27
In a larger sense, what was it like for these people?
bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0054.28
What were the effects of a false allegation of child abuse on the people that were subject of that allegation?
bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0054.29
This study examined the experience of a formerly intact middle-class family, victimized by false allegations of child and sexual abuse.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0054.30
It examines not only the facts, but the ethos, the experience of being innocent and on the wrong side of public opinion, and the power of the state.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0054.31
The Problem
bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0054.32
The National Study of Child Abuse (Smith, 1985) estimated that 1.1 million child abuse and neglect reports have been filed with Child Protective Agencies each year and that more than 600,000 of these probably cannot be substantiated even using the broad definitions of child abuse and neglect often used by the protective service agencies.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0054.33
Of the remaining 40%, only half (or 20% of the total reports) were considered substantial enough to be included in the national study (Smith, 1985).
bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0054.34
<a href="http://www.ipt-forensics.com/journal/volume2/j2_4_7.htm">http://www.ipt-forensics.com/journal/volume2/j2_4_7.htm</a>
bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0055.1
From Kirkus Reviews Â· A psychologist castigates his own profession for its role in false sexual abuse claims that have put innocent people behind bars, ruined families, and damaged patients in therapy.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0055.2
Campbell, a member of the Professional and Scientific Advisory Board of the False Memory Syndrome Foundation, has previously published portions of the present work in a number of peer-reviewed journals.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0055.3
Here, he first examines the role of anxious parents, ill-informed health-care professionals, and overzealous prosecutors in legal cases involving false allegations of sexual abuse.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0055.4
He describes numerous disturbing cases, some that have been well publicized and others that have not, to reveal the error-prone procedures for assessing child abuse and the way in which play therapy for children can dramatically alter their memories.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0055.5
Next, he looks closely at the practice of recovered memory therapy, in which therapists persuade adult clients that their troubles originated in childhood sexual abuse, memories of which they have repressed.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0055.6
Campbell contends that recovered memory therapists, who may be doctoral-level psychologists, not just marginally trained practitioners, are bringing discredit to psychotherapy with their use of the blame-and-change approach (clients in therapy must blame family members in order to change themselves) and their persistence in clinging to misinformed theories about memory and repression.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0055.7
Campbell, who cites studies showing that therapists rely much more on subjective impressions than on scientific research, charges that within the American Psychological Association and other member organizations, political correctness and marketing concerns prevail over ethical responsibility and accuracy of information.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0055.8
In his final chapter, Campbell outlines the changes that he thinks psychotherapy must make, the likelihood of which he finds remote.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0055.9
A hard-hitting indictment - full of appalling human stories, impressive research, tough language, and charges that demand a response.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192821-6703828_0055.10
-- Copyright Â©1998, Kirkus Associates, LP. All rights reserved.

Jena 6 teen's return to jail draws queries Â· Judge's probation ruling called 'revenge'
bolt-eng-DF-199-192823-6758982_0037.3
By Howard Witt | Tribune senior correspondent Â· October 13, 2007
bolt-eng-DF-199-192823-6758982_0037.4
HOUSTON - Civil rights leaders and juvenile justice experts on Friday sharply questioned the legality of a judge's surprise decision to send back to jail a black teenager whose prosecution in a racially charged case helped inspire a massive demonstration in the small Louisiana town of Jena last month.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192823-6758982_0037.5
Attorneys for Mychal Bell, 17, said they would quickly appeal the decision made late Thursday by LaSalle Parish District Judge J.P. Mauffray to revoke Bell's probation and sentence him to 18 months in juvenile detention on two counts of simple battery and two counts of criminal destruction of property.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192823-6758982_0037.6
Bell's juvenile convictions on those charges preceded and were unrelated to a Dec. 4 assault on a white student at Jena High School for which Bell and five other black students, known as the Jena 6, are still awaiting trial in a case that national civil rights leaders say exemplifies unequal treatment of blacks in the mostly white town.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192823-6758982_0037.7
Mauffray's ruling Thursday night came just two weeks after he was forced to release Bell on $45,000 bond after the teenager had been jailed for more than nine months on the Dec. 4 charges.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192823-6758982_0037.8
A Louisiana appellate court overturned Bell's aggravated battery conviction in that case on the grounds that Mauffray had improperly allowed the youth to be tried as an adult.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192823-6758982_0037.9
The appellate court ordered the case back to juvenile court.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192823-6758982_0037.10
"This is judicial revenge," said Al Sharpton, one of the civil rights leaders who have taken up the Jena 6 case.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192823-6758982_0037.11
"The judge was already defeated once by the appellate court, and now he's taking his frustrations out on Mychal Bell."
bolt-eng-DF-199-192823-6758982_0037.12
It was unclear why Mauffray decided to send Bell to jail on the prior charges.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192823-6758982_0037.13
The judge has ordered all the proceedings in Bell's case to be closed and directed all the lawyers in the case not speak about it publicly.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192823-6758982_0037.14
Other experts on Louisiana's juvenile laws said that Mauffray's decision to jail Bell on the earlier charges appeared to run counter to the state's juvenile statutes.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192823-6758982_0037.15
"I don't know the motivation for this judge and the district attorney, but what they did goes against the grain of our own juvenile code, which holds that home and the community is the best place to treat juveniles," said David Utter, an attorney and founder of the Juvenile Justice Project of Louisiana.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192823-6758982_0037.16
Utter is representing one of the Jena 6 defendants.

<a href="http://us.oneworld.net/article/view/127600/1/">300,000 Syrian Kurds 'Buried Alive'</a>
bolt-eng-DF-199-192909-6670315_0017.2
Here's a shortened version, click headline above for full article:
bolt-eng-DF-199-192909-6670315_0017.3
Abid Aslam Â· OneWorld US Â· Feb. 14, 2006
bolt-eng-DF-199-192909-6670315_0017.4
They went to sleep as Syrians and woke up stripped of their citizenship and their rights to study, work, or marry as they wish.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192909-6670315_0017.5
Such was the fate of 120,000 Syrian Kurds who became people with no country in 1962, when they were purged from the Syrian population in a politically motivated one-day census, the Washington, D.C.-based humanitarian group Refugees International said in a new report Tuesday.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192909-6670315_0017.6
Today, their ranks have swollen to 300,000 and their plight is such that one Syrian Kurdish man interviewed by the group described it as "like being buried alive."
bolt-eng-DF-199-192909-6670315_0017.8
The Kurds disowned in 1962 officially were branded "foreigners" but since they enjoyed citizenship nowhere else, they were condemned to statelessness.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192909-6670315_0017.9
They have only spotty access to education, health care, and employment--rights enjoyed by other Syrians, the report said.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192909-6670315_0017.10
They face difficulty in owning businesses and property.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192909-6670315_0017.11
"Even registering a marriage, traveling outside of the country or changing one's residence is a particular challenge for Syrian Kurds," Refugees International said.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192909-6670315_0017.13
Those hardships are faced not only by the generation written off in 1962 but also by their heirs.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192909-6670315_0017.15
The government recognizes Kurdish children's right to primary education but stateless Kurds face trouble getting into secondary school and college, according to Refugees International.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192909-6670315_0017.16
Stateless Kurds also are barred from government jobs and from practicing law or medicine.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192909-6670315_0017.17
They are allowed to work in some, but not all, teaching and engineering jobs.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192909-6670315_0017.18
Stateless Kurdish men cannot legally marry Syrian women, according to the report.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192909-6670315_0017.19
Kurds are barred from using their language in conversation, publications, and in the naming of their children.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192909-6670315_0017.20
They face interrogation, detention, and torture, according to the report.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192909-6670315_0017.21
All this is the result of a 1962 census officially conducted to identify foreigners said to have crossed the border from Turkey illegally, Refugees International said.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192909-6670315_0017.22
In fact, it added, the head-count formed part of a drive to 'Arabize' Syria's resource-rich northeast.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192909-6670315_0017.23
''To retain their citizenship, Kurds had to prove residence in Syria prior to 1945, but many Kurds with proof of residence lost their nationality anyway,'' the organization said.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192909-6670315_0017.24
The issue has haunted Syria and periodically has spilled over into public protest, regional uprisings and, in 2004, major race rioting sparked by a soccer match, according to rights watchdog Amnesty International.

killing two Hamas military activists."

bolt-eng-DF-199-192909-6674527_0176.18

Suicide Blast Kills 18 in Northern Israel Â· JERUSALEM (AP) - A Palestinian suicide bomber blew himself up in a crowded Mediterranean beach restaurant Saturday, killing at least 18 people.

bolt-eng-DF-199-192909-6674527_0257.4

Israel to expand settlement
bolt-eng-DF-199-192909-6674527_0258.3
Israel has launched a tender for the construction of 550 new homes in Jewish settlements in the West Bank.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192909-6674527_0258.4
Almost all the houses will be built in the ultra-Orthodox settlement of Beitar Elit, near Jerusalem.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192909-6674527_0258.5
The announcement comes a day after the government agreed plans to build protective fences around several West Bank settlements.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192909-6674527_0258.6
About 400,000 Israelis live in the West Bank and East Jerusalem, in settlements widely regarded as illegal under international law.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192909-6674527_0258.7
The Israeli housing ministry says this decision is part of its policy to create more housing across the whole of Israel, not just the occupied territories.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192909-6674527_0258.8
It was, according to a spokesman, intended "to develop the communities in accordance with their needs and natural growth".
bolt-eng-DF-199-192909-6674527_0258.9
Despite international laws banning settlement in occupied areas, Jewish settlement building has expanded continually since Israel's occupation of the West Bank and Gaza in 1967, increasing rapidly in the late 1970s when the current Prime Minister, Ariel Sharon, was housing minister.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192909-6674527_0258.10
The pressure group Peace Now said the latest decision showed the housing ministry was acting as "a master planner for the settlers".
bolt-eng-DF-199-192909-6674527_0258.11
Housing Minister Effi Eitam is a member of the far-right National Religious Party, which has close links with the settlers.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192909-6674527_0258.12

Presidency of Theodore Roosevelt 1901â1909
bolt-eng-DF-199-192956-6535368_0002.4
On September 6, President McKinley was shot while at the Pan-American Exposition in Buffalo, New York.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192956-6535368_0002.5
Initial reports in the succeeding days suggested his condition was improving, so Roosevelt embarked on a vacation at Mount Marcy in northeastern New York.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192956-6535368_0002.6
He was returning from a climb to the summit on September 13 when a park ranger brought him a telegram informing him that McKinley's condition had deteriorated, and he was near death.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192956-6535368_0002.7
Roosevelt and his family immediately departed for Buffalo.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192956-6535368_0002.8
When they reached the nearest train station at North Creek, at 5:22 am on September 14, he received another telegram informing him that McKinley had died a few hours earlier.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192956-6535368_0002.9
Roosevelt arrived in Buffalo that afternoon, and was sworn in there as President at 3:30 pm by U.S. District Judge John R. Hazel.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192956-6535368_0002.10
Roosevelt kept McKinley's cabinet and promised to continue McKinley's policies.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192956-6535368_0002.11
One of his first notable acts as president was to deliver a 20,000-word address to Congress[51] asking it to curb the power of large corporations (called "trusts").
bolt-eng-DF-199-192956-6535368_0002.12
For his aggressive attacks on trusts over his two terms, he has been called a "trust-buster."
bolt-eng-DF-199-192956-6535368_0002.13
In the 1904 presidential election, Roosevelt won the presidency in his own right in a landslide victory.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192956-6535368_0002.14
His vice president was Charles Fairbanks.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192956-6535368_0002.15
Roosevelt also dealt with union workers.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192956-6535368_0002.16
In May 1902, United Mine Workers went on strike to get higher pay wages and shorter workdays.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192956-6535368_0002.17
He set up a fact-finding commission that stopped the strike, and resulted in the workers getting more pay for fewer hours.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192956-6535368_0002.18
In August 1902, Roosevelt was the first president to be seen riding in an automobile in public.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192956-6535368_0002.19
[52] This took place in Hartford, CT. The car was a Columbia Electric Victoria Phaeton, manufactured in Hartford.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192956-6535368_0002.20
The police squad rode bicycles alongside the car.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192956-6535368_0002.21
(The reference includes a photo of the event.)
bolt-eng-DF-199-192956-6535368_0002.22
In 1905, he issued a corollary to the Monroe Doctrine, which allows the United States to "exercise international policy power" so they can intervene and keep smaller countries on their feet.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192956-6535368_0002.23
Roosevelt helped the wellbeing of people by passing laws such as The Meat Inspection Act of 1906 and The Pure Food and Drug Act.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192956-6535368_0002.24
The Meat Inspection Act of 1906 banned misleading labels and preservatives that contained harmful chemicals.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192956-6535368_0002.25
The Pure Food and Drug Act banned food and drugs that are impure or falsely labeled from being made, sold, and shipped.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192956-6535368_0002.26
Roosevelt was also served as honorary president of the school health organization American School Hygiene Association from 1907 to 1908, and in 1909 he convened the first White House Conference on the Care of Dependent Children.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192956-6535368_0002.27
The Gentlemen's Agreement with Japan came into play in 1907, banning all school segregation of Japanese, yet controlling Japanese immigration in California.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192956-6535368_0002.28
That year, Roosevelt signed the proclamation establishing Oklahoma as the 46th state of the Union.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192956-6535368_0002.29
Building on McKinley's effective use of the press, Roosevelt made the White House the center of news every day, providing interviews and photo opportunities.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192956-6535368_0002.30
After noticing the White House reporters huddled outside in the rain one day, he gave them their own room inside, effectively inventing the presidential press briefing.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192956-6535368_0002.31
The grateful press, with unprecedented access to the White House, rewarded Roosevelt with ample coverage.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192956-6535368_0002.32
He chose not to run for another term in 1908, and supported William Taft for the presidency, instead of Fairbanks.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192956-6535368_0002.33
Fairbanks withdrew from the race, and would later support Taft for re-election against Roosevelt in the 1912 election.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192956-6535368_0002.34
List of federal judges appointed by Theodore Roosevelt
bolt-eng-DF-199-192956-6535368_0002.35
Roosevelt appointed a record 75 federal judges.
bolt-eng-DF-199-192956-6535368_0002.36
Roosevelt appointed three Justices to the Supreme Court of the United States: Oliver Wendell Holmes, Jr. (1902), William Rufus Day (1903), William Henry Moody (1906).
bolt-eng-DF-199-192956-6535368_0002.37
In addition to these three, Roosevelt appointed 19 judges to the United States Courts of Appeals, and 53 judges to the United States district courts.

bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0057.1
Let's look at what the US EPA says on its site:
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0057.2
Scientists know for certain that human activities are changing the composition of Earth's atmosphere.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0057.3
Increasing levels of greenhouse gases, like carbon dioxide (CO2 ), in the atmosphere since pre-industrial times have been well documented.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0057.4
There is no doubt this atmospheric buildup of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases is largely the result of human activities.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0057.5
Nevertheless, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) stated there was a "discernible" human influence on climate; and that the observed warming trend is "unlikely to be entirely natural in origin."
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0057.6
In the most recent Third Assessment Report (2001), IPCC wrote "There is new and stronger evidence that most of the warming observed over the last 50 years is attributable to human activities."
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0057.7
As atmospheric levels of greenhouse gases continue to rise, scientists estimate average global temperatures will continue to rise as a result.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0057.8
By how much and how fast remain uncertain.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0057.9
IPCC projects further global warming of 2.2-10Â°F (1.4-5.8Â°C) by the year 2100.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0057.10
This range results from uncertainties in greenhouse gas emissions, the possible cooling effects of atmospheric particles such as sulfates, and the climate's response to changes in the atmosphere.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0057.11
The IPCC states that even the low end of this warming projection "would probably be greater than any seen in the last 10,000 years, but the actual annual to decadal changes would include considerable natural variability."
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0057.12
IPCC cautions, "Complex systems, such as the climate system, can respond in non-linear ways and produce surprises."
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0057.13
The fundamental scientific uncertainties are these: How much more warming will occur?
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0057.14
How fast will this warming occur?
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0057.15
And what are the potential adverse and beneficial effects?
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0057.16
These uncertainties will be with us for some time, perhaps decades.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0057.17
Global warming poses real risks.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0057.18
The exact nature of these risks remains uncertain.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0057.19
Ultimately, this is why we have to use our best judgement - guided by the current state of science - to determine what the most appropriate response to global warming should be.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0057.20
From the <a href="http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/oa/climate/globalwarming.html#Q1" title="http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/oa/climate/globalwarming.html#Q1" target="_EXT">National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration</a>
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0057.21
Human activity has been increasing the concentration of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere (mostly carbon dioxide from combustion of coal, oil, and gas; plus a few other trace gases).
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0057.22
There is no scientific debate on this point.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0057.23
Pre-industrial levels of carbon dioxide (prior to the start of the Industrial Revolution) were about 280 parts per million by volume (ppmv), and current levels are about 370 ppmv. The concentration of CO2 in our atmosphere today, has not been exceeded in the last 420,000 years, and likely not in the last 20 million years.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0057.24
According to the IPCC Special Report on Emission Scenarios (SRES), by the end of the 21st century, we could expect to see carbon dioxide concentrations of anywhere from 490 to 1260 ppm (75-350% above the pre-industrial concentration).
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0057.25
Large and rapid climatic changes affecting the atmospheric and oceanic circulation and temperature, and the hydrological cycle, occurred during the last ice age and during the transition towards the present Holocene period (which began about 10,000 years ago).
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0057.26
Based on the incomplete evidence available, the projected change of 3 to 7Â°F (1.5 - 4Â°C) over the next century would be unprecedented in comparison with the best available records from the last several thousand years.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0057.28
Graph showing roughly 1000 years of temperature in the northern hemisphere.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0057.29
It is based on combined data from ice layers, corals, trees, etc. The 20th Century's one degree Fahrenheit warming stands out dramatically.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0057.31
Over a 40 year period, scientist Charles Keeling measured the amount of carbon dioxide (CO2) in the atmosphere.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0057.32
The above "Keeling Curve" shows the increase in total concentrations of CO2 in the atmosphere from 1957-1997.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0057.33
This unbroken record of the carbon dioxide content of the atmosphere shows how it's gone up, in round numbers, from around 315 parts per million to around 370 parts per million on average today.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0057.34
This data is widely accepted by everyone.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0057.36
Graph showing a 450,000 year record of carbon dioxide (CO2) levels in the earth's atmosphere.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0057.37
This record was compiled from analyzing bubbles of fossilized air trapped in ice cores.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0057.38
The fossilized air shows the levels of carbon dioxide and other gases in the atmosphere throughout this 450,000 period.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0057.39
The last 100-150 years of the 20th Century show a significant rise in CO2.

bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0064.1
Global warming is 'twice as bad as previously thought'
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0064.2
By Steve Connor, Science Editor Â· 27 January 2005
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0064.3
Global warming might be twice as catastrophic as previously thought, flooding settlements on the British coast and turning the interior into an unrecognisable tropical landscape, the world's biggest study of climate change shows.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0064.4
Researchers from some of Britain's leading universities used computer modelling to predict that under the "worst-case" scenario, London would be under water and winters banished to history as average temperatures in the UK soar up to 20C higher than at present.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0064.5
Globally, average temperatures could reach 11C greater than today, double the rise predicted by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, the international body set up to investigate global warming.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0064.6
Such high temperatures would melt most of the polar icecaps and mountain glaciers, raising sea levels by more than 20ft.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0064.7
A report this week in The Independent predicted a 2C temperature rise would lead to irreversible changes in the climate.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0064.8
The new study, in the journal Nature, was done using the spare computing time of 95,000 people from 150 countries who downloaded from the internet the global climate model of the Met Office's Hadley Centre for Climate Prediction and Research.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0064.9
The program, run as a screensaver, simulated what would happen if carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere were double those of the 18th century, before the Industrial Revolution, the situation predicted by the middle of this century.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0064.10
David Stainforth of Oxford University, the chief scientist of the latest study, said processing the results showed the Earth's climate is far more sensitive to increases in man-made greenhouse gases than previously realised.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0064.11
The findings indicate a doubling of carbon dioxide from the pre-industrial level of 280 parts per million would increase global average temperatures by between 2C and 11C.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0064.12
Mr Stainforth said: "An 11C-warmed world would be a dramatically different world...
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0064.13
There would be large areas at higher latitudes that could be up to 20C warmer than today.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0064.14
The UK would be at the high end of these changes.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0064.15
It is possible that even present levels of greenhouse gases maintained for long periods may lead to dangerous climate change...
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0064.16
When you start to look at these temperatures, I get very worried indeed."
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0064.17
Attempts to control global warming, based on the Kyoto treaty, concentrated on stabilising the emissions of greenhouse gases at 1990 levels, but the scientists warned that this might not be enough.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0064.18
Mr Stainforth added: "We need to accept that while greenhouse gas levels can increase we need to limit them, level them off then bring them back down again."
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0064.19
Professor Bob Spicer, of the Open University, said average global temperature rises of 11C are unprecedented in the long geological record of the Earth.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0064.20
"If we go back to the Cretaceous, which is 100 million years ago, the best estimates of the global mean temperature was about 6C higher than present," Professor Spicer said.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0064.21
"So 11C is quite substantial and if this is right we would be going into a realm that we really don't have much evidence for even in the rock [geological] record."
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0064.22
Myles Allen, of Oxford University, said: "The danger zone is not something we're going to reach in the middle of the century; we're in it now."
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0064.23
Each of the hottest 15 years on record have been since 1980.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0064.24

bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0110.1
STUDY BOLSTERS GREENHOUSE EFFECT THEORY, SOLVES ICE AGE MYSTERY
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0110.2
COLUMBUS, Ohio - Critics who dismiss the importance of greenhouse gases as a cause of climate change lost one piece of ammunition this week.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0110.3
In a new study, scientists found further evidence of the role that greenhouse gases have played in Earth's climate.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0110.4
In Thursday's issue of the journal Geology, Ohio State University scientists report that a long-ago ice age occurred 10 million years earlier than once thought.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0110.5
The new date clears up an inconsistency that has dogged climate change research for years.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0110.6
Of three ice ages that occurred in the last half-billion years, the earliest ice age posed problems for scientists, explained Matthew Saltzman, assistant professor of geological sciences at Ohio State.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0110.7
Previous studies suggested that this particular ice age happened during a time that should have been very warm, when volcanoes all over the earth's surface were spewing carbon dioxide (CO2) and other heat-trapping greenhouse gases into the atmosphere.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0110.8
With CO2 levels as much as 20 times higher than today, the late Ordovician period (460-440 million years ago) wasn't a good time for growing ice.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0110.9
Critics have pointed to the inconsistency as a flaw in scientists' theories of climate change.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0110.10
Scientists have argued that today's global climate change has been caused in part by buildup of CO2 in the atmosphere resulting from fossil fuel emissions.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0110.11
But, critics have countered, if CO2 truly raises global temperatures, how could an ice age have occurred when a greenhouse effect much greater than today's was in full swing?
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0110.12
The answer: This particular ice age didn't begin when CO2 was at its peak -- it began 10 million years earlier, when CO2 levels were at a low.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0110.13
"Our results are consistent with the notion that CO2 concentrations drive climate."
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0110.14
Saltzman and doctoral student Seth Young found that large deposits of quartz sand in Nevada and two sites in Europe -- Norway and Estonia -- formed around the same time, 440 million years ago.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0110.15
The scientists suspect that the sand formed when water levels fell low enough to expose quartz rock, so that wind and rain could weather the rock into sand.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0110.16
The fact that the deposits were found in three different sites suggests that sea levels may have been low all over the world at that time, likely because much of the planet's water was bound in ice at the poles, Saltzman said.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0110.17
Next, the scientists examined limestone sediments from the sites and determined that there was a relatively large amount of organic carbon buried in the oceans -- and, by extension, relatively little CO2 in the atmosphere -- at the same time.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0110.18
Taken together, the evidence suggests that the ice began to build up some 10 million years earlier than when volcanoes began pumping the atmosphere full of the CO2 that ended the Ordovician ice age.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0110.19
For Saltzman, the find solves a long-standing mystery.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0110.20
Though scientists know with a great degree of certainty that atmospheric CO2 levels drive climate change, there are certain mismatches in the geologic record, such as the Ordovician ice age -- originally thought to have begun 443 million years ago -- that seem to counter that view.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0110.21
"How can you have ice when CO2 levels are through the roof?
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0110.22
That was the dilemma that we were faced with.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0110.23
I think that now we have good evidence that resolves this mismatch," Saltzman said.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0110.24
Scientists at the three sites previously attributed these quartz deposits to local tectonic shifts.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0110.25
But the new study shows that the conditions that allowed the quartz sand to form were not local.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0110.26
"If sea level is dropping globally at the same time, it can't be a local tectonic feature," Saltzman said.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0110.27
"It's got to be the result of a global ice buildup."
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0110.28
Saltzman wants to bolster these new results by examining sites in Russia -- where he hopes to find more evidence of sea level drop -- and in parts of South America and North Africa, which would have been covered in ice at the time.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0110.30
<a href="http://researchnews.osu.edu/archive/earlyice.htm" title="http://researchnews.osu.edu/archive/earlyice.htm" target="_EXT">Source</a>

bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0156.3
Global warming: scientists reveal timetable
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0156.4
By Michael McCarthy, Environment Correspondent Â· 03 February 2005
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0156.5
A detailed timetable of the destruction and distress that global warming is likely to cause the world was unveiled yesterday.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0156.6
It pulls together for the first time the projected impacts on ecosystems and wildlife, food production, water resources and economies across the earth, for given rises in global temperature expected during the next hundred years.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0156.7
The resultant picture gives the most wide-ranging impression yet of the bewildering array of destructive effects that climate change is expected to exert on different regions, from the mountains of Europe and the rainforests of the Amazon to the coral reefs of the tropics.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0156.8
Produced through a synthesis of a wide range of recent academic studies, it was presented as a paper yesterday to the international conference on climate change being held at the UK Met Office headquarters in Exeter by the author Bill Hare, of the Potsdam Institute for Climate Impact Research, Germany's leading global warming research institute.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0156.9
The conference has been called personally by Tony Blair as part of Britain's attempts to move the climate change issue up the agenda during the current UK presidency of the G8 group of rich nations, and the European Union.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0156.10
It has already heard disturbing warnings from the latest climate research, including the revelation on Tuesday from the British Antarctic Survey that the massive West Antarctic ice sheet might be disintegrating - an event which, if it happened completely, would raise sea levels around the world by 16ft (4.9 metres).
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0156.11
Dr Hare's timetable shows the impacts of climate change multiplying rapidly as average global temperature goes up, towards 1C above levels before the industrial revolution, then to 2C, and then 3C.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0156.12
As present world temperatures are already 0.7C above the pre-industrial level, the process is well under way.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0156.13
In the near future - the next 25 years - as the temperature climbs to the 1C mark, some specialised ecosystems will start to feel stress, such as the tropical highland forests of Queensland, which contain a large number of Australia's endemic plant species, and the succulent karoo plant region of South Africa.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0156.14
In some developing countries, food production will start to decline, water shortage problems will worsen and there will be net losses in GDP.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0156.15
It is when the temperature moves up to 2C above the pre-industrial level, expected in the middle of this century - within the lifetime of many people alive today - that serious effects start to come thick and fast, studies suggest.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0156.16
Substantial losses of Arctic sea ice will threaten species such as polar bears and walruses, while in tropical regions "bleaching" of coral reefs will become more frequent - when the animals that live in the coral are forced out by high temperatures and the reef may die.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0156.17
Mediterranean regions will be hit by more forest fires and insect pests, while in regions of the US such as the Rockies, rivers may become too warm for trout and salmon.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0156.18
In South Africa, the Fynbos, the world's most remarkable floral kingdom which has more than 8,000 endemic wild flowers, will start to lose its species, as will alpine areas from Europe to Australia; the broad-leaved forests of China will start to die.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0156.19
The numbers at risk from hunger will increase and another billion and a half people will face water shortages, and GDP losses in some developing countries will become significant.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0156.20
But when the temperature moves up to the 3C level, expected in the early part of the second half of the century, these effects will become critical.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0156.21
There is likely to be irreversible damage to the Amazon rainforest, leading to its collapse, and the complete destruction of coral reefs is likely to be widespread.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0156.22
The alpine flora of Europe, Australia and New Zealand will probably disappear completely, with increasing numbers of extinctions of other plant species.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0156.23
There will be severe losses of China's broadleaved forests, and in South Africa the flora of the Succulent Karoo will be destroyed, and the flora of the Fynbos will be hugely damaged.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0156.24
There will be a rapid increase in populations exposed to hunger, with up to 5.5 billion people living in regions with large losses in crop production, while another 3 billion people will have increased risk of water shortages.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0156.25
Above the 3C raised level, which may be after 2070, the effects will be catastrophic: the Arctic sea ice will disappear, and species such as polar bears and walruses may disappear with it, while the main prey species of Arctic carnivores, such as wolves, Arctic foxes and the collared lemming, will have gone from 80 per cent of their range, critically endangering predators.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0156.26
In human terms there is likely to be catastrophe too, with water stress becoming even worse, and whole regions becoming unsuitable for producing food, while there will be substantial impacts on global GDP.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0156.27
<a href="http://news.independent.co.uk/world/environment/story.jsp?story=607254" title="http://news.independent.co.uk/world/environment/story.jsp?story=607254" target="_EXT">Source</a>

bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0259.1
Future climate could be hotter than thought - study Â· Wed Jun 29, 2005
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0259.2
By Patricia Reaney
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0259.3
LONDON (Reuters) - Global temperatures in the future could be much hotter than scientists have predicted if new computer models on climate change are correct, researchers said on Wednesday.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0259.4
Improvements in air quality will lead to a decrease in aerosols, small particles in the atmosphere that act as a brake on the impact of greenhouse gases.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0259.5
As the effect of aerosols lessen, searing temperatures could follow.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0259.6
"This new way of integrating the aerosol, greenhouse gas and biosphere effects changes the picture from one where climate change most likely is a fairly tolerable thing to one where there is a fairly high risk of change sooner, and to a higher degree," said Professor Meinrat Andreae.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0259.7
The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) predicts a rise in global temperatures from a doubling of carbon dioxide could be in the range of 1.5-4.5 degrees Celsius by the end of the century.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0259.8
But according to calculations by Andreae and his team, the upper figure could be as high as 6 degrees.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0259.9
"That's quite a lot," the professor from the Max Planck Institute for Chemistry in Mainz, Germany said in an interview.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0259.10
Andreae compared greenhouse gases to an accelerator that is speeding up global warming, while the aerosols act as a type of brake.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0259.11
"The actual true force of the greenhouse gases has been masked by the effects of the aerosols.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0259.12
They put a brake on warming and we don't really know how strong that brake is," said Andreae, who reported his findings in the journal Nature.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0259.13
Scientists have warned that severe climate change could lead to a rise in sea levels, flooding, severe droughts and the loss of crop and animals species.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0259.14
Aerosols are small particles and droplets in the air from combustion processes, chemicals and smoke.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0259.15
As regulatory agencies issue new air purity controls, the amount of aerosols will diminish so their cooling effect will be smaller.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0259.16
Aerosols stay in the atmosphere for about a week but greenhouse gases accumulate over about 50 years.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0259.17
The aerosol brake is going to come off faster than the decrease in greenhouse gases.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0259.18
"Because one is cumulative and the other is not, the cumulative will always win out in the long run," said Andreae.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0259.19
He admitted it was a situation of high scientific uncertainty.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0259.20
But if his calculations are correct, climate change in the 21 century could reach the upper extremes or exceed the IPCC estimates.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0259.21
"Such a degree of climate change is so far outside the range covered by experience and scientific understanding that we cannot with any confidence predict the consequences for the Earth system," Andreae said in the journal.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0259.22

bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0352.5

bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0369.7
You are correct.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0369.8
I should have written:
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0369.9
Dilemma: Increasing some emissions in the atmosphere increases the percentage of the sun's radiation that is deflected by the atmosphere away from Earth's surface; increasing CO2 in the atmosphere increases the percentage of the heat radiated from Earth's surface that is deflected back to Earth's surface.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0369.10
(Both CO2 and those other emissions are emitted by industry, electric power plants, vehicles and other burners of carbon-based fuels.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0369.11
Decreasing CO2 emissions will probably require decreasing those other emissions as well.)
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0369.12
<a href="http://www.gcrio.org/CONSEQUENCES/winter96/sunclimate.html" title="http://www.gcrio.org/CONSEQUENCES/winter96/sunclimate.html" target="_EXT">www.gcrio.org/CONSEQUENCES/winter96/sunclimate.html</a>
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0369.13
[ boldface added by ican ]
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0369.14
The Sun and Climate Â· by Judith Lean and David Rind Â· ...
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0369.15
In global average, increases in greenhouse gas concentrations or in solar radiation bring warmer surface temperatures since they add energy to the climate system.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0369.16
In contrast, increased industrial and volcanic aerosols restrict the penetration of solar radiation to the Earth's surface and lead to surface cooling.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0369.17
A drop in the concentration of ozone in the lower stratosphere should also produce a net cooling at the surface.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0369.18
Changes in albedo that increase the planet's reflectivity will lead to cooling, and those that make it less reflective and more absorbing, to a temperature rise.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0369.20
The Earth receives most of its direct heat from the visible and near- infrared spectrum of sunlight, retaining about 70 percent of what pours down on its day-lit hemisphere.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0369.21
The rest is returned, by reflection, back into the cold of space.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0369.22
A part of what the ground and oceans and lower atmosphere absorb also leaks outward through the atmosphere in the form of infrared radiation.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0369.23
The remaining fraction--trapped in part by greenhouse gases--sustains the habitable environment to which we are accustomed.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0369.24
Any variation in total radiation from the Sun will force an accompanying change in mean-surface temperature.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0369.26
As for your Mars argument..
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0369.27
Like Earth, Mars has seasons that cause its polar caps to wax and wane.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0369.28
"It's late spring at the south pole of Mars," says planetary scientist Dave Smith of the Goddard Space Flight Center.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0369.29
"The polar cap is receding because the springtime sun is shining on it."
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0369.30
The reported melting of the polar ice caps on Mars is more than a seasonal melt just as it is on earth now.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0369.31
It is allegedly a general trend throughout all of Mar's seasons.

Seems that the UK's prime minister has changed his mind on global warming, and has decided to follow his supervisor's lead:
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0370.2
Blair falls into line with Bush view on global warming
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0370.3
By Geoffrey Lean and Christopher Silvester
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0370.4
Published: 25 September 2005
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0370.5
Tony Blair has admitted that he is changing his views on combating global warming to mirror those of President Bush - and oppose negotiating international treaties such as the Kyoto Protocol.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0370.6
His admission, which has outraged environmentalists on both sides of the Atlantic, flies in the face of his promises made in the past two years and undermines the agreement he masterminded at this summer's Gleneagles Summit.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0370.7
And it endangers talks that opened in Ottawa this weekend on a new treaty to combat climate change.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0370.8
The U-turn will inevitably bring accusations that he has, once again, sold out to Mr Bush, just at the time that the US President is coming under unprecedented pressure to change his policy in the wake of hurricanes Katrina and Rita.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0370.9
Last week the UK Government's chief scientific advisor, Sir David King, said that global warming might have increased their severity.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0370.10
Over the past two years Mr Blair has consistently claimed global leadership in tackling what he described as "long term, the single most important issue we face as a global community" and has stressed that it "can only properly be addressed through international agreements".
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0370.11
President Bush repeatedly expressed anger at his position.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0370.12
Sharing a platform with the US Secretary of State, Condoleezza Rice, in New York this month, Mr Blair confessed: "Probably I'm changing my thinking about this", adding that he hoped the world's nations would "not negotiate international treaties".
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0370.13
This contradicts his assertion in a speech a year ago - which drew a private rebuke from the Bush administration - that "a problem that is global in cause and scope can only be fully addressed through international agreement".
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0370.14
It also denies what his ministers claimed to be his main achievement on global warming at Gleneagles.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0370.15
He had succeeded in getting all the leaders except Mr Bush to sign up to negotiating a successor to the Kyoto treaty, and in arranging a meeting between the G8 and leading developing countries to discuss it.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0370.16
But instead of endorsing agreed limits on the pollution that causes climate change, Mr Blair told this month's meeting at the Clinton Global Initiative that he was putting his faith in "developing science and technology" - precisely Mr Bush's position.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0370.17
He justified his change of heart by saying that countries would not negotiate environmental treaties that cut their growth or consumption - another of the President's main contentions.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0370.18
But in another speech last April he said it was "quite false" to suppose that environmental protection would inhibit growth.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0370.19
Last night, Tony Juniper, executive director of Friends of the Earth, called the Prime Minister's volte-face "unbelievable": "Having failed to practise what he preaches, he is now changing his preaching to match his practice."
bolt-eng-DF-199-193260-6566899_0370.20
