bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0126.20
What sense does it make to have David Miliband toil away for a year rethinking local government and the cities, only to move him before his work is done to focus on the countryside?
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0126.21
Far from bringing in fresh blood, Blair was forced to recirculate blood that's been in the system a long, long time.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0126.22
No one embodies that better than John Reid, arch-Blairite henchman now elevated to the Home Office - his sixth cabinet post in five years.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0126.23
Reid gives good Newsnight, but rejuvenating he ain't [..]
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0126.25
But the objections to this reshuffle went deeper than that.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0126.26
For nothing about it suggested a prime minister preparing the ground for the "orderly transition" which he himself necessitated nearly two years ago, when he announced that he would not seek a fourth term.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0126.27
More importantly nothing in this reshuffle signalled an eventual handover to Brown at all.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0126.28
On the contrary, the PM simply dug in, surrounding himself with Blairite ultras.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0126.29
The promotion of Reid, the retention of Tessa Jowell are part of it; but even more provocative was the appointment of Hazel Blears as party chairman.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0126.30
If Blair had a transition in mind, he would have picked a neutral for the job; or even someone allied to Brown, say Douglas Alexander, to smooth the way.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0126.31
He would also have brought on a new generation, giving them precious experience, ready to serve a new administration.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0126.32
Instead the PM selected a team to help him finish the job, rather than to prepare for the next phase of the Labour government.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0126.33
What he installed yesterday was a Final Days administration.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0126.34
The great irony is that the conventional sequence of such a day is for a disastrous poll result to be rescued by a sparkling reshuffle.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0126.35
Yet yesterday it was almost the other way around: it was the ministerial rejig, rather than the council elections, which drew attention to the fundamental weaknesses of the government.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0126.36
For on its own, Thursday night was not the disaster it might have been.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0126.37
Labour could have haemorrhaged 400 seats, rather than 250; its share of the vote could have fallen to less than a quarter, rather than 26%.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0126.38
In the event, Labour could claim to have held firm, not falling below its 2004 local performance, which was followed by a general election win.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0126.39
There were even some gains, Lambeth in London and extra seats in Manchester, Sheffield and Barnsley.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0126.40
But that was not the mood yesterday.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0126.41
For there was a winner on Thursday and his name is David Cameron.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0126.42
He took his party to the psychologically important 40% threshold for the first time since 1992.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0126.43
It's not yet the national surge the Conservatives need: Manchester, Liverpool and Newcastle remain stubbornly Tory-free zones.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0126.44
But gains in London and the south east, in Hammersmith and Croydon, are not to be sneezed at either.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0126.45
As one anxious Labour strategist put it yesterday: "Seats like those, remember, are the New Labour majority."
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0126.46
The Labour party is beginning to see the possibility of defeat, on the distant horizon maybe, but, for the first time in a decade, visible.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0126.47
They are desperate to renew themselves before the voters decide they are clapped out and should be turfed out.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0126.48
They want Tony Blair to get that message - and, if he doesn't listen, some of them are ready to make him.

Tony Blair is amazing.

Splits, resignations, media frenzy, calls for a new leader.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0163.4
It all sounds incredibly familiar to someone who has worked for John Major and William Hague.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0163.5
So I thought my Blairite friends in Downing Street and elsewhere might enjoy the benefit of my experience:
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0163.6
1. You will be tempted to call for unity.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0163.7
Calls for unity never work.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0163.8
2. You are quite right, you are surrounded by nutters.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0163.9
But the funny thing about nutters is that they don't appreciate being called mad.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0163.10
Don't bother, therefore, attacking your internal opponents.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0163.11
3. You were quite wrong.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0163.12
Things can't only get better.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0163.13
4. Every cunning plan you dream up for diverting the news agenda will fail.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0163.14
Don't think that getting Margaret Beckett to make a speech on CAP reform will move your splits down the news.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0163.15
5. There is nothing you can do.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0163.16
Nothing.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0163.17
And therefore the best thing you can do is.....
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0163.18
6. Nothing.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0163.19
The only card the Prime Minister still has is incumbency.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0163.20
He should keep his head down, keep his mouth shut, and keep going.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0163.21
This will fail to work, but do so less spectacularly than anything else.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0163.22
Oh and.....
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0163.23
7. Don't write anything down.

the quotation marks around the "resigned" are correct..

In his own resignation letter, Watson explains how it happened:
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0164.6
As you know, I had a conversation with the chief whip last night, in which she asked me to withdraw my support from the 2001 intake's letter calling on you to stand down, or my position would be untenable as a government minister.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0164.7
I have reflected on this overnight.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0164.8

<a href="http://politics.guardian.co.uk/labourleadership/story/0,,1866017,00.html" title="http://politics.guardian.co.uk/labourleadership/story/0,,1866017,00.html" target="_EXT">Full text of Tom Watson's letter</a>

His letter is admirably plainspoken, at least relative to the standards of this Blairite age, by the way.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0164.11
The impression you get is of someone who truly believed in the Labour Party-make 2; that is, one of that rare breed of New Labourites-by-conviction.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0164.12
The sheer naivity he expresses in his dreamlike impressions of how
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0164.13

bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0164.16
The Labour party has been my life since I was 15 years old.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0164.18

bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0164.19

bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0164.20

bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0164.21

bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0164.22
I share the view of the overwhelming majority of the party and the country that the only way the party and the government can renew itself in office is urgently to renew its leadership.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0164.23

bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0164.25
For the sake of the legacy you have long said is the only one that matters - a renewed Labour party re-elected at the next general election - I urge you to reconsider your determination to remain in office.

bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0309.4

bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0309.5
The result would give the party 42% of the vote against Labour on 29%, similar to its performance under Michael Foot in 1983.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0309.6
The Liberal Democrats would drop to 17%.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0309.7
The result is the highest that the Conservatives have scored in any ICM poll since July 1992, just after their last general election victory.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0309.8
The question, which names all three major party leaders, asks voters to think about politics in a different way from the standard ICM question about voting intentions, which only names parties.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0309.9
As such, it is a greater test of the personality of each party leader, or potential leader.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0309.11

bolt-eng-DF-199-193409-6487537_0309.12

bolt-eng-DF-199-193488-6644828_0102.1
<a href="http://www.salon.com/opinion/greenwald/" title="http://www.salon.com/opinion/greenwald/" target="_EXT">GLENN GREENWALD: Facts and myths about Obama's preventive detention proposal</a>
bolt-eng-DF-199-193488-6644828_0102.2
Excerpt:
bolt-eng-DF-199-193488-6644828_0102.4
(1) What does "preventive detention" allow ?
bolt-eng-DF-199-193488-6644828_0102.5
It's important to be clear about what "preventive detention" authorizes.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193488-6644828_0102.6
It does not merely allow the U.S. Government to imprison people alleged to have committed Terrorist acts yet who are unable to be convicted in a civilian court proceeding.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193488-6644828_0102.7
That class is merely a subset, perhaps a small subset, of who the Government can detain.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193488-6644828_0102.8
Far more significant, "preventive detention" allows indefinite imprisonment not based on proven crimes or past violations of law, but of those deemed generally "dangerous" by the Government for various reasons (such as, as Obama put it yesterday, they "expressed their allegiance to Osama bin Laden" or "otherwise made it clear that they want to kill Americans").
bolt-eng-DF-199-193488-6644828_0102.9
That's what "preventive" means: imprisoning people because the Government claims they are likely to engage in violent acts in the future because they are alleged to be "combatants."
bolt-eng-DF-199-193488-6644828_0102.10
Once known, the details of the proposal could -- and likely will -- make this even more extreme by extending the "preventive detention" power beyond a handful of Guantanamo detainees to anyone, anywhere in the world, alleged to be a "combatant."
bolt-eng-DF-199-193488-6644828_0102.11
After all, once you accept the rationale on which this proposal is based -- namely, that the U.S. Government must, in order to keep us safe, preventively detain "dangerous" people even when they can't prove they violated any laws -- there's no coherent reason whatsoever to limit that power to people already at Guantanamo, as opposed to indefinitely imprisoning with no trials all allegedly "dangerous" combatants, whether located in Pakistan, Thailand, Indonesia, Western countries and even the U.S.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193488-6644828_0102.13
(6) Is it "due process" when the Government can guarantee it always wins ?
bolt-eng-DF-199-193488-6644828_0102.14
If you really think about the argument Obama made yesterday -- when he described the five categories of detainees and the procedures to which each will be subjected -- it becomes manifest just how profound a violation of Western conceptions of justice this is.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193488-6644828_0102.15
What Obama is saying is this: we'll give real trials only to those detainees we know in advance we will convict.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193488-6644828_0102.16
For those we don't think we can convict in a real court, we'll get convictions in the military commissions I'm creating.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193488-6644828_0102.17
For those we can't convict even in my military commissions, we'll just imprison them anyway with no charges ("preventively detain" them).
bolt-eng-DF-199-193488-6644828_0102.18
Giving trials to people only when you know for sure, in advance, that you'll get convictions is not due process.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193488-6644828_0102.19
Those are called "show trials."
bolt-eng-DF-199-193488-6644828_0102.20
In a healthy system of justice, the Government gives everyone it wants to imprison a trial and then imprisons only those whom it can convict.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193488-6644828_0102.21
The process is constant (trials), and the outcome varies (convictions or acquittals).
bolt-eng-DF-199-193488-6644828_0102.22
Obama is saying the opposite: in his scheme, it is the outcome that is constant (everyone ends up imprisoned), while the process varies and is determined by the Government (trials for some; military commissions for others; indefinite detention for the rest).
bolt-eng-DF-199-193488-6644828_0102.23
The Government picks and chooses which process you get in order to ensure that it always wins.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193488-6644828_0102.24
A more warped "system of justice" is hard to imagine.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193488-6644828_0103.1

JOSE PADILLA v. JOHN YOO
bolt-eng-DF-199-193488-6644828_0108.2
<a href="http://lawprofessors.typepad.com/files/padilla-yoo.pdf" title="http://lawprofessors.typepad.com/files/padilla-yoo.pdf" target="_EXT">http://lawprofessors.typepad.com/files/padilla-yoo.pdf</a>
bolt-eng-DF-199-193488-6644828_0108.3
ORDER DENYING IN PART AND GRANTING IN PART DEFENDANT'S MOTION TO DISMISS
bolt-eng-DF-199-193488-6644828_0108.4
Filed 6/12/09
bolt-eng-DF-199-193488-6644828_0108.5
Excerpts:
bolt-eng-DF-199-193488-6644828_0108.6
* * * Like any other government official, government lawyers are responsible for the foreseeable consequences of their conduct....
bolt-eng-DF-199-193488-6644828_0108.7
* * * the Court finds Padilla has alleged sufficient facts to satisfy the requirement that Yoo set in motion a series of events that resulted in the deprivation of Padillaâs constitutional rights....
bolt-eng-DF-199-193488-6644828_0108.8
Padilla alleges with specificity that Yoo was involved in the decision to detain him and created a legal construct designed to justify the use of interrogation methods that Padilla alleges were unlawful.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193488-6644828_0108.9
* * * The allegation that Padilla was denied any access to counsel for nearly two years is sufficient to state a claim for violation of his right to access to courts....
bolt-eng-DF-199-193488-6644828_0108.10
* * *Padilla alleges that Yoo bears responsibility for the conditions of his confinement due to his drafting opinions that purported to create legal legitimacy for such treatment.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193488-6644828_0108.11
Therefore, although Padillaâs claim must be analyzed under the Due Process provision of the Fourteenth Amendment and not pursuant to the Eighth Amendment, the Eighth Amendment sets the bar below which the treatment of detainees should not fall.
bolt-eng-DF-199-193488-6644828_0108.12

bolt-eng-DF-200-192400-6257046_0003.2

bolt-eng-DF-200-192400-6257046_0003.3
It doesn't really matter whether anyone has told you that you are depressed or not, you are obviously having some problems at the minute and could use some support- labels aren't as important as your experiences.
bolt-eng-DF-200-192400-6257046_0003.4
Meditation and exercise are really helpful, so definitely try to do those.
bolt-eng-DF-200-192400-6257046_0003.5
But yeah, you will have to engage with help and life in general to get somewhere- but don't beat yourself up about feeling unmotivated to do anything at the minute, lots of people feel like this and hopefully it will pass as you begin to feel better.
bolt-eng-DF-200-192400-6257046_0003.6
